awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Improving Distributed Teamwork Through Mobile Robotic Telepresence Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This research systematically investigates the impact of specific Mobile Robotic Presence (MRP) system features on formal and informal collaboration across different levels of analysis, including teamwork, informal communication, and the social network structure of an organization.  MRP systems are audio and video conferencing systems mounted on a mobile base, operated by someone a distance away from the location, and often serving as a surrogate for people who cannot travel there, for any of a number of reasons.  Geographically distributed teams and organizations have been shown to suffer in comparison to those that are collocated, in part because conventional computer-mediated communication tools fail to support both formal meetings and informal interactions during activities like walking the hallway or waiting for the elevator that help build work relationships and provide valuable information about the organizational.  MRP systems are a promising new technology for distributed teamwork because they can support both formal and informal workplace interactions.  The project will develop new tools and knowledge for communication across geographic distance that will be made widely available to the research community and general public. It will also enhance education through graduate student training and the development of new classroom tools, curriculum, and diversity outreach efforts.  

Specifically, the project aims to: (a) develop a systematic understanding of the effects of telepresence robots on formal and informal workplace communication through a series of lab and field studies; (b) develop and evaluate a set of interface and control techniques that improve informal and formal communication; (c) examine how the introduction of MRPs into an organization influences the structure of its social network using social network analysis; and (d) integrate the techniques and findings at the interface, team and organizational levels through a set of field studies.  The research will contribute to the fields of computer-mediated communication and computer-supported cooperative work by developing new theories and understandings of how people interact via telepresence robots in both formal group meetings and informal interactions. It will contribute to human-computer interaction, robotics, and related fields through the development of new techniques and tools for interacting with and through telepresence robots. It will contribute to theories of how distance affects organizational structure by exploring the network-level effects of working remotely via MRPs vs. conventional computer-mediated communication tools. Finally, the project will help build new understandings of the relationships among individual features of MRP technology, the usefulness of that technology for distributed collaboration, and its effects on organizational structure.

por.por_cntn:
In modern organizations, people are frequently distributed across geographic distance. People participate remotely in projects, and new organization structures have emerged that rely on large parts of their work being done by distributed groups. Conventional technologies for remote collaboration such as video conferencing are often not sufficient to support all the different activities teams engage in, especially those requiring mobility in the workplace.

This project investigated whether and how mobile telepresence robots can provide better support for distributed team and organizational activities. Mobile telepresence robots consist of an audio/video conferencing system mounted on a mobile base that a remote user can move through a workspace. Telepresence robots are unique in that they can support both formal collaborative activities (e.g., meetings) and informal engagement such as chance encounters while traversing hallways. 

Based on over a dozen user studies, the project provided a deeper understanding of how the presence of telepresence robots in team activities affects team dynamics and people?s engagement with and through the robots. For example, studies showed that group structure, group power dynamics, and the distribution of information across team members affect the ways that people engage with telepresence robots. Studies also show how the presence of telepresence robots affects team decision-making.

The project also provided insights into how specific features of these robots affect use of these robots. For example, our results showed that automated telepresence robots that can move on their own to a selected target are more efficient, but people prefer manually manipulating these robots.

Finally, we developed new algorithms, techniques, and capabilities for telepresence robots to make them easier to use, including a pedestrian prediction algorithm and a social navigation algorithm that have demonstrated value for helping people navigate telepresence robots. In addition, we built a vortex canon that can be used by pilots of telepresence robots to engage with people remotely, to get their attention. Finally, we added features for lateral movement and video capture.

Intellectual merit: The project systematically investigated the impact of specific telepresence robot features (e.g., field of view, presence of an arm) on formal and informal collaboration across different levels of analysis, including teamwork, informal communication and the social network structure of an organization.  Specifically, the project aimed to: (a) develop a systematic understanding of the effects of telepresence robots on formal and informal workplace communication through a series of lab and field studies; (b) develop and evaluate a set of interface and control techniques that improve informal and formal communication via telepresence robots; (c) examine how the introduction of telepresence robots into an organization influences the structure of its social network using social network analysis; and (d) integrate the techniques and findings at the interface, team and organizational levels through a set of field studies.

Broader impacts: The project had broader impacts in at least four ways.  First, it led to new tools, algorithms, and knowledge for communication across geographic distance that have been made widely available to the research community and general public.  Second, it enhanced education through the training of 20 PHD students and over 100 undergraduate and Master?s students. The project also led to the development of new classroom tools, demos and exercises that allow students to experience collaboration through a telepresence robot and reason about how to improve it.  Third, the project increased diversity in STEM disciplines through the inclusion of women and underrepresented minority students from diverse backgrounds in our projects. We also engaged in outreach efforts to middle and high school girls.  Fourth, the results have provided, and will continue to provide, societal benefit by leading to the development of telepresence robots that make it easier for remote workers to become fully engaged in the activities of an organization.
